title: Scale Construction
content: So hopefully by now you have the hang of major scale construction, now it’s time to learn about minor scale construction. Don’t worry, it’s very similar, but we use a different interval pattern. Let’s get right into it by constructing C minor!

title: Minor Scales
content: Here’s the interval pattern for minor scales. It’s very similar to that of major scales, so be careful you don’t mix them up!

title: C minor: C
content: So once again, we know the first note of the scale: C. The first interval in the pattern is a tone, so we move up from C to D and add it to the scale.

title: C minor: C D
content: Now the first difference from major scales - we have a semitone. A semitone up from D is Eb, so we add this to the scale.

title: C minor: C D Eb
content: A tone, so we move from Eb to F.

title: C minor: C D Eb F
content: Another tone, so we move from F to G.

title: C minor: C D Eb F G
content: A semitone, so we move from G to Ab.

title: C minor: C D Eb F G Ab
content: A tone, so we move from Ab to Bb.

title: C minor: C D Eb F G Ab Bb
content: A tone, so we move from Bb back to our tonic, C.

title: Minor Scales
content: So there we go, C minor! If you’ve got the hang of this, the hardest part should be remembering the difference between the major and minor patterns, but it just takes practice. In the quiz, have a go at constructing A minor!
